author: Aaron Flanagan
title: Joe Hart admits he is "surplus to requirements" at Manchester City - and might NOT return to Premier League
text:
Get football   Could   
Joe Hart has admitted that his Manchester City career is over. 
The England No.1 believes that he will not be given a second chance to prove himself under Pep Guardiola despite Claudio Bravo's calamitous debut season. 
City could be on the lookout for a new stopper altogether after Willy Caballero was promoted to first-choice at the Etihad. 
Hart has spent the season on loan at Serie A club Torino after losing his place in the team at the start of the season. 
The 29-year-old has admitted that it is highly unlikely that Guardiola will go back on his word and offer him a place back at City. Hart was benched by Guardiola at the start of the season (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) Bravo took the reigns at City's No.1 (Photo: PA) Read More Joe Hart's future remains uncertain, admits agent 
"I'd say I'm pretty much surplus to requirements at my parent club at the moment," Hart said, speaking on the BBC's Premier League show. "I have got to be realistic. 
"I love that club and I have always said, as long as they want me, I will be there. 
"I want to play football and I love to play football, so if that opportunity is not going to be given there, then I am going to have to look elsewhere and I may have to make somewhere else my home." 
That new home might not be in the Premier League. Hart signed for Torino at the start of the season (Photo: Getty) His arrival got a big reaction on the streets of Turin (Photo: Getty) 
Torino have admitted that they would like to keep Hart in Turin beyond his season-long loan but the Â£20million price tag hanging over his head might prove to be problematic. 
Hart is at risk of losing his place as England's first-choice, despite recent assurances from Gareth Southgate, and insists that he needs to pick a club where he is guaranteed to play. 
"I'm open," Hart said, when asked if a return to English domestic action. 
"I love the Premier League and I absolutely love Premier League games. Hart insists that he could remain abroad (Photo: Getty) Hart has ad assurances from Southgate over his future (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) 
"Remove myself as a footballer and I still watch the Premier League. It's a great league and fantastic football is played in it. I know it really, really well. 
"But I wouldn't say it is top of my wishlist. 
"Top of my wishlist is to play for a club who wants me to be their goalkeeper." 
Hart claims that being axed by Guardiola was not a surprise to him. 
He claims that he could sense something was not working out when the former Barcelona boss took over last summer. Guardiola appears to have made his mind up on Hart's future (Photo: Getty) A return to Manchester City might not be an option for Hart (Photo: Getty) Read More Torino chief explains why Hart could make permanent switch 
But Hart says that he has no qualms with Guardiola for making the decision. 
"I saw it coming," Hart said. "You just pick up vibes and it certainly wasn't a surprise to me. 
"It was something that I wanted to change and I thought I was more than capable of changing, but to get results, he had to have a team that he felt comfortable with and a team that he wanted. 
"I didn't fall into that category and it's no problem. Hart has enjoyed the experience of playing abroad (Photo: 2017 Getty Images) He hopes that he has a future as England's first choice goalkeeper (Photo: The FA via Getty) 
"I'd love to have stayed and fought and shown what I can do, but I do not have that time. You do not have that time, especially as a goalkeeper. 
"You can't come off the bench for 10 minutes and prove your worth - you're either in or you're out. 
"I'm all up for a fight. I'll fight my corner all day. But if you're not going to win, there is no point in fighting, especially with someone as powerful as that at Manchester City. 
"It's nothing personal on me. I know it is nothing personal on me. He's not that kind of guy." poll loading Should Joe Hart return to the Premier League next season? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
